comment: Super easy professor with a LOT OF extra credit. No final exams. 2 mark-up exams for the lowest grade exams. the exam are really based on the template but make sure you understand the material. He is easy and hard grader at the same time. He will minus a lot if you have error he mentioned in class. SUPER GOOD CLASS!

Dr. Noring is amazing. DO THE HOMEWORK. It's not much if you spread it out and he offers so much extra credit just from doing the homework (uses Achieve). I had him for Calc 1 2 and 3 and I'd gladly take him again. He articulates things well and gives in depth answers to questions asked. He's accessible outside of class and answers emails quickly.

DO. THE. HOMEWORK.

EVERY LAST BIT OF IT.

DO IT.

if you do, even if you average like a 50 on exams you can still get a C

Dr. Noring is a very tough grader but if you follow the guidelines AND DO THE HOMEWORK you'll be fine.

Also, if he offers extra credit, DO IT. Doesn't matter how long it takes, it's worth it.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Professor Noring is easily the best math professor I've ever had.  He makes Calc 3 easy and will help you if you need it.  His tests have a memorization section where you can write your formulas, and he posts practice exams with answers.  USE THESE!  Do 60% of the homework and you get extra credit.  Easy A, I wish I had studied more.

His teaching style is specific, he may seem off topic but he relates it back to the problem later, so he's not for you if you're easily distracted. He's an engineer teaching so future engineers can succeed, often relating things to engineering, which usually isn't helpful for non-engineers, but he is fantastic. I highly recommend Dr. Noring.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: Definitely recommend him if you're naturally good at math and want to breeze by an easy course. He's so funny and nice and gives so much extra credit. Took him for calc 2 and 3.

He frequently goes on tangents and I can understand why others may not like him but I think he's a good professor. He doesn't just teach you how to solve a problem, he puts emphasis on the importance of actually understanding the content. There definitely is a lot of homework, but exposure to a variety of problems is important.

Overcomplicates simple concepts, and on top of that he completely glosses over complicated concepts, talks about engineering more than math, reads straight from the book, many other issues. Would absolutely not recommend.

Likes to yap about things that are not on topic; almost all learning must be done outside of class. Attendance is mandatory, and if you miss 5 classes, you automatically get a C or lower. He seems like a nice guy, but he is an awful teacher. He reads straight from the book but then talks about how much he hates the book. Overall, bad experience.

Noring should take a public speaking course. He is a bright guy, but has subpar communication skills and an inability to break down complex problems. "Cluttered" is the word I would use to describe his teaching style. 
It felt like Noring spent more time choosing his syllabus font or making his template exams look pretty than planning each class.

I have mixed feelings about him. He cares a lot and gives you everything you need for success. 8 tests, memorization parts (formulas). the amount of homework is insane, especially at the start and he goes on a rant about the education system in almost every class. Overall it was a lot of work and a bit frustrating but I did learn.

Dr. Noring's class is definitely challenging. He expects students to quickly grasp new material and often goes off-topic, which can make it difficult to stay on track. The class is very self-learning and demands a lot of independent study.

The class was tough with tons of tests and a big final but I liked it. The teacher pushed us when we messed up which helped even if it felt harsh. He gave practice tests so we knew what to study, and the homework was hard but rewarding. He focused on the "why" instead of just the "what". I know many hated it cause he didn't spoon feed everything.

If you can DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS!! He does not teach and spent the entire semester reading straight from the text book. I consider myself good at math, and struggled understanding anything material he taught. He spent more time ranting about nonsense then lecturing about math. He does not prepare you for any test!!

Professor Noring is by far one of my worst professors I have had. Here are a few things that make him so: Not accessible outside of class, goes off topic in lectures, and calls students blatantly stupid. He believes everyone should understand calculus already and pushes the importance of the subject without teaching it.

He's very passionate about the subject. But because calculus stuck to him so easy, he has a difficult time understanding that others don't collect information like he does. He's kind, but he's math-brained and thinks everyone be like that. ALEKS teaches you more than he does with an overload of homework and half won't prepare you for the tests.

If you took AP Calc, take this class. Easy A
If you have no basis of calc, you shouldn't take this class
Fantastic Grading
Bad lectures
8 Exams
Practice exams 
Extra credit questions
Homework
100-200 homework questions per exam
Only 70% to receive full credit
Homework due at semester end
Few homework modules that are extra credit

This course isn't too difficult with a solid algebra foundation, but Professor Noring is a poor lecturer. He frequently goes on irrelevant engineering tangents, disregarding non-engineering students. He also lacks a clear teaching plan— seemingly choosing problems and subtopics randomly. 
Don't count on getting an email response from him either!

DO NOT TAKE HIM. He assigns so much homework, at least 100 problems a week and the homework AFFECTS THE TEST GRADE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! He is not caring, he goes off on long winded tangents about random things. He teaches as if his students have seen the material before!

If you can avoid this professor, do so. I do not understand how he even has a 3.8 on here, his lectures are deathly boring and goes on tangents all class. The homework is absurd and it takes him 3 weeks to grade the tests.

The class is challenging, but Professor Noring makes it manageable. Doing lots of practice problems is key. Attend lecture and use resources like the SI sessions and unstuckstudy ai - they really help consolidate the material. Overall, a tough but rewarding course.
He is not a good teacher. I did not learn anything at all. Go to SI sessions if you have him. Wont learn anything from him.

Took Professor Noring's class over the summer. Definitely was difficult due to the fact that Calc II has a lot of content, and we only had 8 weeks. I understand where the bad reviews are coming from, but overall it really isn't that bad. He even gave template exams that were pretty similar, trig heavy albeit for his real exams. He's a solid choice.

Jon Noring is the best Calculus professor I've ever had. Before this class, I often struggled with understanding the concepts of calculus and working out tough questions. Tests are like the study guide, homework can be helpful, but can be somewhat time consuming. My favorite thing about him is how he stresses fundamentals and thorough

Dr. Noring is the professor to take if you need Calculus as an Engineering student. His grading criteria are very clear and all of the homework is available on day 1. The study guides he uploads are the same as his exams so if you study and work every problem out thoroughly, you will excel on the exams.

Dr Noring is a pretty good professor overall, his lectures can be a bit boring, but you can tell he cares a lot about explaining why math is important and where it is used in life. The tests are exactly the same format as the practice tests he posts online, but they're still really difficult. You got to know your trig and algebra to do well in this

He had 8 exams, but they felt more like quizzes because he'd post template exams with the same problems just different numbers. Great lectures, I felt like he made the concepts easy enough to understand. He is willing to accommodate students but hard for me to reach him via email. Do show up to class, but if you miss a few, you'll be okay

Professor Noring is pretty boring on the lecture side, but the way his class is setup is amazing. Bonus points for attendance and extra homework. His tests are slightly difficult if you don't know your algebra and trig, but are easy enough to pass. He also includes study guides a day or two before the test. For Calc3 a MUST take. Other profs SUCK!

Professor Noring spent most of the lectures explaining why we should learn something instead of actually teaching that topic. Homework was very repetitive and often wasn't about what he was teaching. Often went on tangents about his days as an engineer instead of teaching. I only got an A because I taught myself at home. I would take someone else.
GOAT

You learn almost nothing from the actual lecture. You learn everything from the homework, which he never stops talking about doing. That is honestly fine but the problem is that he assigns SO MUCH REPETITIVE HOMEWORK. My class was three times a week, and every lecture had a new homework assignment that would average 30 to 90 questions.

He does "teach through the book", but if that's your main take away, you didn't pay attention. He doesn't just hang over the board and rework book questions, but explains in detail WHY things are the way they are and HOW each topic works. He spends the majority of the lecture teaching you how to think like a calculus based mathematician/engineer.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Guy's a good professor, he likes to stress importance of the topics based on how they relate to real world. He taught well and I understood the concept fine but there was a lot to memorize which is what I mainly struggled with. There's a decent amount of extra credit offered on the homeworks and through attendance, enough to nudge you up a few pts.

His lectures are really good and he answers questions well. The class was challenging but not impossible by any means but my main issue is I saw some heavily consistent cheating on tests which was frustrating. I probably shouldve said something which is on me but I didnt know if I would be roped into the situation so I didnt. That was my big issue.

Dr. Noring has a great ability to express exactly what he wants from us and what he wants to teach. He gives us all the necessary materials to pass including extra homework and other stuff. All that is expected is to work hard and put in the effort. If you don't do the homework you will fail. Like any other college class.

LOTS of homework (currently uses MyLabMath). Good lectures as long as you pay attention, gives good advice outside of just learning math. Will show how to apply the math based on your major. Understands that most of his students are Engineering or computer Science majors.

Calculus II/Math 1190 is a difficult and broad subject to begin with, but Professor Noring teaches it in a digestible way. You will pass the class if you do the homework, but you must Do. The. Homework. It's only by doing hundreds of problems will you master the subject. Noring is very passionate about what he teaches. I highly recommend him.

I, unfortunately, had to withdraw from the class due to the position I was in with grades and test scores, however, Professor Noring was completely understanding & kind, attempted to work with me, and gave me many opportunities and adaptations in respect to my learning disabilities. Would really recommend as I had a 1-on-1 meeting that helped lots.

Not as bad as some of these reviews make him sound but he's not the best either. Class is very passable if you do all homework and extra credit. Also show up to class as you receive extra credit for that. Very test heavy class, 1000/1100 of the points your grade is made up of come from the 8 tests and the final.

He is an ok professor. Class is made up of 8 quizzes, final and homework. Attendance gives you extra credit. He is a very tough grader, if you don't show working out the way he wants you will lose so many points. I wouldn't recommend taking him unless your'e really good at math. However, he does curve at the end of the semester which helps.

His class is not very difficult, as he releases template exams that are identical to the actual exam. However, he is not a very good teacher. He teaches principles, skipping on how to actually do them. Only reason I did well was the SI, she was amazing. He does care about his students, attempting to help them and grading tests pretty generously.

Noring is a great professor. He has template exams that are very similar to the actual test. If you understand the processes and strategies used on the template exam, you'll easily pass the exams. I also recommend doing the homework throughout the semester. Overall pretty easy class. Take Noring if you can!
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Going to his lectures were a waste of my time. I learned more in one SI session than I did in two weeks worth of his lectures. I truly don't know how he got all of these 5's.

Whatever you do, do not take him. Absolutely terrible. Did not prepare us for the final whatsoever. There was tons of content on the final that he did not cover but every other calc professor did. I do not know what is wrong with him.

Jon is a nice guy and seems to care about the students but he is an absolutely terrible teacher. The lectures are sporatic and hard to follow. Goes on constant tangents about how hes an engineer and we need to know this stuff for engineering. The only saving graces are the test templates. Coming into finals he has covered little of the actual stuff
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: he didn't really teach in class and relied on the textbook. The SI helped me and taught me the whole course. is really heavy on homework and there's so many problems. his saving grace is that his practice tests and like his actual tests, and memorization portion is actually helpful in the course. He's a nice guy, but goes on tangents a lot.

This professor is the epitome of terrible. He relies HEAVILY on online work to make up for his inability to teach the course. As students, we spend WAY too much money on an IN-PERSON course for it to be taught 90% online. Do NOT take this course unless you want to retake it next semester.
we have a test every other week. he takes off so many points on the tests just for him to not teach. if noring is your last option as a professor, just don't take the class at all.
do not take this dude you will regret it. he only teaches conceptual stuff and rarely does any actual examples. he gives 8 tests, one every other week, and lots of HW

8 tests. SI is the only reason I'm passing. A lot of graded hw through MyLab Math some are 80q. No quizzes, optional lecture, but if you go, it's extra credit. Grade is made on tests, you can retake 1 at the end of the semester. Template exam is your friend use it. Goes on random tangents. Tries to snap his fingers... emphasis on tries.

All he does is read off the textbook. Homework is abysmal. It's on Pearson, 50+ questions long, and half the time you haven't even learned it in class (the completion of some of these directly correlate to your grade on some of the tests). His only saving grace is that his template exams are very similar to the test (which is one every other week).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Worst professor I have ever had he does not teach and the SI teaches this class entirely. He should not be a professor and alters his ratings on this. DO NOT TAKE!!!

DO NOT TAKE!!!!!!!!!!! I just came out of Pre-calc with a 99 and am struggling to understand almost every concept in this class. I only attend class for the extra credit. The SI Audrey is a life saver she makes the concepts he teaches seem so basic. she is the reason people in this class have A's and the reason I have done well on the past exams.

if ur a bio major... AVOID. He mentions engineering at least one or twice a lecture and how IMPORTANT what he is "teaching" is. YET DOESNT TEACH IT. IF YOU ARE A VISUAL LEARNER, AVOID!!!!!! TAKE ANY OTHER PROFESSOR. Ive basically been teaching myself everything and watching youtube videos. save yourself and run. hes a good man but bad teacher
You cannot slack in this class. Keep up with weekly homework (ALEKS) and go to tutoring! He talks about the content you need to know for calc and gets frustrated when we don't know the material.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: the only warning label i'd give for him is you need to be ready to try. ask questions in class he's very good at explaining problems in depth. he also talks about calc a lot but over good teacher. Very chill. ALOS PLEASE STUDY THE SYLLABUS IN DEPTH.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Spent more time complaining and talking about other classes than teaching. Gets angry when we dont get something but fails to fully teach us or rushes. Lack of respect and privacy for students. Told us that if we can't understand something then we are not meant for college. Only learned from the SMART center. I did not gain anything from him.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: As seen in the reviews Professor Noring may be an amazing Calc professor but as an algebra professor, he is very difficult. He is very strict with the way you should be showing your work on an exam, and tells us to learn from our homework but then complains about our homework not being a proper way for us to learn. Do not take his algebra class!
Save yourself.

AWFUL. His lectures are useless, and goes on constant tangents about Calculus and how "public school failed us". Tests are much harder than the homework, which is on ALEKS. Gives template exams, which are helpful, but gives barely enough time to do them. Class average on the first test was a 50. Be prepared to teach yourself the content.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Please don't take his algebra class! Dr. Noring rambles about calculus at least once every class, when we are literally in college algebra. The exam templates are released like 2 days before the exam, and the questions are completely foreign. He relies on Aleks to teach us, but the topics never cover the ones on the exam.
He didn't even talk about algebra just calculus.
All he does is talk about calc.

He just talked about other classes he taught for most of the lecture and was not very clear with his teachings. Homework did not accurately portray how the exams would be. Good reviews were posted a few days before the exam which are helpful. He's chill but mid.

Constantly talks about calc so if you are taking a class other than calc you are out of luck. he also tells you after every equation that it is extremely important... he doesn't really help he just speaks and half the time he is off topic. many classes he barely gets through three problems a class and wont stay on topic. WOULDN'T RECOMMEND!
All he does is talk about calculus.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: He is an okay professor, his tests are hard and this class literally sucks up all your time cause of amount of hw he assigns. Also constantly talks about engineering and other things not related to the course making hard to know what you actually need for calc 2. I do not advise taking if you can't do hw or study lots. It's a full time job.

Honestly, Professor Noring isn't a bad person himself. His teaching style on the other hand is horrible and almost impossible to learn from. Relies on the textbook to do the teaching. For much of the class, you will be teaching yourself and for many of the tests, the class average was rarely above a C. Take at your own risk.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment:
He cares about the students who are willing to give it their all.
The hw is 40-80 questions (27 hws) the average is worth a test grade he gives 20 bonus pts if the score is over 100. The tests ARE HARD u must ask questions to clarify things, but the test templates give basic ideas, u have to be INSANELY good in algebra before taking his class.

Dr. Noring knows what to teach you to prepare you for the next course (Calc 3 or Differential equations) but his method of teaching does not help his students learn. solving easy problems on the board but giving much harder problems on the exam does not help. That, along with rambling about off topic subjects, makes his class much harder.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Noring is a good professor for Mechanical, Civil, or Structural engineers. Although he is very organized. When he lectures he tends to get off topic, which makes if hard to focus. There is a test weekly and homework is required to be 80% completed or your test grade will be affected. Memorization is key in this class!
He’s solid I would not suggest him, there are definitely better options. Also, he gives lots of homework. Noring gives 8 test so the test come quick.

Don't sign up for his class! He never prepares lesson plans before class and instead relies on the textbook to "teach" almost everything - most of his "lectures" are him rambling through textbook definitions and pointing at the steps to the example problems instead of actually doing or explaining anything, and he assigns insane amounts of homework.

I took his class, and all the horrible reviews he has are spot on. I’m pretty sure he wrote 95% of the good reviews hisself and if you’re crazy enough to take his class then I’m sure you will agree with me. Exact same things he says in class. This man should not be a professor. He thinks everyone is as smart as he is. AVOID AT ALL COSTs

In lectures all he talked about was how you can use a kitty cat face instead of x. Never taught anything. 3 weeks and I had no notes. Assigned tons of homework and expected you to teach yourself. This man should not be a professor. You’re here to TEACH, not tell people teach yourself. May as well just get a cal book and teach yourself

Be prepared to teach yourself Calculus 2. His lectures are just reading the textbook and just going over the book examples and that's it. You have a test ever week and half and have to do 100+ problems before the test. The test are extremally harder than the homework. Insane amount of algebra skills is need for his test. Avoid him at all cost.

Loved this professor! He was really nice and very fair. Tests are super similar to the practice tests, so really make sure you understand and study those. Tons of extra credit opportunities! Only some of the homework counts as a grade, so a lot ends up being extra credit.

If you learn by doing practice problems only. This course is for you. If you need more help because youre not very good at math choose someone else. Doesnt hold your hand in the course. Hopefully this gives you an idea if you plan on taking math1111 to calc3 with him. * must know trig and algebra before coming in or you might struggle.*

I took him for Calc 1 & Calc 2. Beware that he nags about completing HW problems every SINGLE class - we get it. Obvi you have to put the work in to get through Calc, so prepare to work. On many of the exams the algebra in the problems was just insane. He offers exam retakes and extra credit on the exams, good luck solving the EC problems.

We have ALEKS homework everyday. Yes theres a template exam but the actual exam is way harder and confusing, he twists it up. He complains about the school system and how we didnt ALREADY know the material. He zooms through literally every problem, so you dont know how he got what he got. Its self taught. No calculators. It was all pain.

5 tests in and I haven't passed one. I've easily devoted more time to this one class then anything ever in college. All this professor does is tell you that you should already know everything. He doesn't teach well at all and most of the problems he does, he speeds through. I haven't learned anything all semester!

Noring was a great teacher, he assigns so many opportunities for bonus points and lets you retake your lowest 2 exams if you do all the homework. He wants to make sure you are prepared for your other classes so he will go over the most important subjects only. Diff Eq was no longer a nightmare.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He makes you work for it because he cares. It's not an easy class, because the material isn't easy, and he wants to make sure you know it backwards and forwards. If you work hard and don't procrastinate, it's totally reasonable to get an A. Pro tip: Do the homework. Do as much of it as you can.

i signed up cuz i read so many good things. AVOID !!!! "lectures" were him ranting us how useful calc is in the real world. all semester, we probably did 4 practice problems. yes, the study guides are SO similar to the exams, but he never TAUGHT THE MATERIAL ! and we were lucky if we got 1 practice problem in 2 hours. i would never take him again.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He grades hard, but he is a nice professor. Be ready to work problems on your own. He expects you to be able to take about a million derivatives lol. Overall the is a good professor.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lots of homework

comment: This class is 100% self taught. He might go over a relevant problem once a month. He goes on tangents about how school systems now are terrible. He grades strictly on tests. I learned nothing from this man all semester. If you dont have a background in calc, you will struggle.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I had Dr. Noring for Calculus 1, and I would definitely take him again for the higher level courses. He shows you how to solve each problem step by step. While his study guides are similar to his exams, do not just rely on them to study. I highly recommend doing as many homework problems as you can every day in order to fully prepare for exams.

he's really not as bad as everyone says. Did he teach me a single thing? no I learned everything from youtube. 12 tests which is way too many, but they are more like quizzes and EXACTLY like the study guide. He also gives bonus points at every chance. Its hard to get an A, but if you put in effort, you will be fine. There are much worse calc profs.

Dr. Noring cares about his students, but that's it. He spends more than half of class time ranting and complaining about things outside of the students' control. DO NOT TAKE. There are much better options. The only reason I did well was because of the SI instructor. The worst professor I have ever taken. Sets his students up for failure.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: WORSE PROFESSOR EVERRRRR!! TEST LITERALLY EVERY SINGLE WEEK!! WHEN HIS CLASS AVERAGE IS LOW AS IN 30S OR 50SBECAUSE LITERALLY EVERYONE FAILED HE'LL GO STRAIGHT TO BLAMING HIS STUDENTS. HE TAKES OFF POINTS ON YOUR TEST IF YOU DONT SHOW YOUR WORK AS MUCH AS HE'D LIKE YOU TO! THIS CLASS IS NOT WORTH THE HEADACHES FIND A BETTER TEACHER!! RUNNNN
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: AVOID AT ALL COST! When he does teach, he teaches as if everyone is going to CALC 3. He is a HEAVY grader. Grades based on your work shown, not your final answer. He grades on the work that he doesn't even teach in class. Spends 80% of class going on rants and not the information we need to succeed. Please save yourself and do not take him!!!

Professor Noring was probably one of the worst professors I have ever had. This man would spend the majority of his lecture time expressing how disappointing it was that we didn't already know the content in the class and ranting about how horrible the school system is. I ended up withdrawing and changing my major because of this class. DONT TAKE!

prof. noring is nice but i have no idea how he has such high ratings. he does not review practice problems in his lectures and is very shallow when describing content. i really only enjoyed his tests because they were very similar to the study guides. if this is your first time with calc/if you don't have a strong trig/algebra background, avoid him
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Definitely should be teaching higher level math. Taught pre calc as if it was one long review session. Explicitly said he was not there to "teach" us. Got annoyed if we did not have prior knowledge of the course or did not quickly learn the material. Said things like "learn the material on your own, use class as review time" and "this is easy"

If youre in stem hes a solid choice. He gets bummed when he finds out students werent taught fundamentals and rants about the education system. His engineer background makes his class slightly catered for engineers. Dont let penalty points add up because it can drop you close to two letter grades if you dont do your hw. Cool professor

Took the Covid-19 version of his class and it was not terrible. He likes to rant during lectures a bit but besides that everything he's says will help you. Made sure to teach practical examples when going over different topics.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Overall nice and caring prof. Really wants you to do well, but you gotta pull your fair weight. Practice exams are literally just the exams but with different numbers. Did ALEKS every time it was due + practice exams and I turned out more than fine. You can retake exams at the end but I didn't need to.

Dr. Noring was an alright teacher. Had him in Spring 2020. He mainly talked about what we need to learn for calculus/calculus itself even though it was a trig class. He does let you retake tests at the end of the semester and provides study guides before each test. I would say I learned more through ALEKS than his lectures. Not a bad teacher tho

The tests are the exact study guide, but, Math is Math. You have to know do to do the problems. He is a nice guy, and is very understanding, but you will not pass if you do not understand the content. There are 8 test total, not including the final. And, after the first 2 weeks, you have a test ALMOST every week. DO aleks.

He's a really nice guy who is truly passionate about what he teaches. With this in mind, he often goes on tangents, and personally I learned very little from his lectures. I however am a terrible student. He grades entirely based on the work, and sometimes can be nit-picky, however I managed to pass thanks to his *amazing* *study guides.*

He's probably a great professor for CALC and CALC II, but dont take him for lower level classes. He uses trig to "prep" you for CALC, all while acknowledging that most of the students will be done with mathematics after they take trig. Used multiple tutors, and every single one claimed that he was going way too in depth for a trig class.

Great professor! Gives great outline of what is expected in the class to get an A. Lecture is required, gives you a chance to makeup any test youve missed or retake any bad test grades! Super fair, and enjoyable professor, you wont regret it!

I can't deny this professor's passion for the subject, however the way he presents the material is horrible. His explanations are not specific and discredits the way the book explains material while still using it as a reference. You must do the work as he showed you or else its invalidated. 12 EXAMS throughout 6 testing periods. (2 per period)

Dr. Noring is great! He is really passionate and goes on rants sometimes, but he goes out of his way to help. Make use of his office hours, they helped me. His exams are very similar to his practice tests, so make sure you study those thoroughly. He gives a bunch of extra credit opportunities that can help as well. I took him for trig and calc!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He was ok. Lectures were him just reading from the textbook or going on a tangent about calc, there was always someone who was asleep. Tests were similar to practice exams but sometimes a little trickier. SI helped a lot, only reason I made a B. Wouldnt recommend for trig bc I think it was harder than necessary but prob good for calc/upper levels

I have not taken math in 2 years, so getting back into it with calculus was a huge shock. However, without Professor Noring, I never would have passed. He gives you everything you need to be successful. I did not realize how difficult this was going to be, but he makes you so prepared. Definitely going to be doing all your learning outside of class

Take this class. It is difficult by nature so you have to put in your own effort. You must be able to dedicate time outside class in order to succeed. Practice exams are very helpful so take time to study them throughly. The hw is annoying cuz Pearson but you get a lot of practice. I withdrew first time I took calc so this was a big step up.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria

comment: It's a no from me. This class was college trig, but somehow became the history of calculus. Minor errors result in major point deductions. Class is mandatory, but you do nothing in it. He never answers his emails. I spoke to him multiple times in person about the email, and he never responded. His grading criteria is a mess and not understandable.

100% of our grade is from his 12 tests. His in class lectures tend to be boring and confusing, but he compensates for it by releasing practice tests that offer an extremely detailed and easy to understand explanation of the problems, and they are essentially the same as his actual tests.

Nice guy, but I have no idea how he got this high of a rating. I have no idea what goes on in class then I get on YouTube and search the topic and understand in 15 minutes. Calc 1 is not hard, his class is.

Prof. Noring was a decent guy, but idk where all the good ratings came from. He moves too fast for anyone to actually understand what was going on, and gave us over 200+ homework questions a week. We also had two tests on one day with not enough time, and I basically had to self teach all the material to stay afloat before deciding to drop.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: If you take him, be prepared to do most learning on your own to do well. (SI sessions, smart center, studying a lot on your own)
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Your best bet is to complete webassign HW while he is going over that topic in class. You'll get bored of him reading the textbook and doing few examples. His whining and ranting may get annoying but he is accessible through email an outside of class and ALWAYS willing to help. If you know the practice test inside and out, you will succeed!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Grading consists of attendance, 8 tests, & homework. If you don't do the homework you will get penalty points & won't get a good grade in the class. Reviews are provided for each test & the questions on the test are just like them. There's a lot of extra credit. If you take his class be ready to watch cat videos & listen to him talk about calculus.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework

comment: Dr. Noring is a really smart professor. He definitely knows what he's talking about and sometimes he'll even go back and explain other concepts so that you get what he's lecturing on. You have to follow along closely to understand though-if you doze off you might miss something and get lost. I say this from personal experience lol! I recommend him
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: i took this guy over the summer, for calc 3 but it wont let me make that selection. he reads the book to you and expects you to figure stuff out since most of his students are going to be engineers. doesn't provide a solid foundation for the class. he also assigns a lot of homework that, he said it himself he just dumps a bunch of problems in d2l.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Do the homework, go to class, study the practice tests, and that's it. He's probably one of the fairest teachers I've ever had. His lectures are also interesting and fun to listen to, which is pretty much a heretical idea amongst math professors, at least in my experience.

This is in my opinion the best prof at KSU. He expects a lot out of his students but gives even more to make sure they do well in his class and breaks the material down into smaller sections so it is much easier to study for. If you are struggling on any concept stop by his office and he is always more than happy to help.

To get an A in this class, here's what you need to know. There are twelve tests total. Go to every lecture, you will get bonus points at the end of the class. Also do the practice exams and the webassignes before their due dates. If you don't understand something, ask him questions. He's always willing to help students during office hours
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Jon Noring is very clear with what he wants you to achieve in the class. For diff eq he gave us a total of 10 tests (supposed to be 12) one over each chapter. As long as you go to class, pay attention and review his old exams (that he puts on the d2l page) you should pass the class without any problems.
Great professor but he gives very few examples, you have to be prepared to figure out the webassign and practice tests on your own

The class consisted of 8 tests with in-class time being devoted to lectures based off of the book. There was HW for each set test however it wasn't worth any points and didn't reflect the exam but if you didn't do it you would lose points. Be ready to study on your own because he tends to ramble during lectures. Not to hard as long as you study
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: He's super smart but with that being said his tests are too hard for a trig course. I'm sure he'd be great for upper levels bc all he talks about is calc. His tests are like 5 questions each so if you mess up just once you make a b. Gives practice exams but the actual test is usually much harder. final grade straight from exam grades
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: He gives 12 tests so every test only has a little material so each one is basically a quiz, just study enough before and you'll be fine. He also gives great study guides for the tests so just study of those and you'll be prepared. Homework is due at the end of the semester. He is super kind and funny. Best professor on campus

He literally reads from the textbook. Not necessarily a bad thing, but just be prepared for a somewhat boring lecture. His practice exams he gives are exactly like the tests, so make sure you can do every problem on there and know the formulas/memorization you need. The class is graded on 12 exams with the final being 2 retakes. 50% homework is req

Traditional lecture style, came here to say that the whole math program should hire learning assistants. Dont know what I would of done without the study sessions. Shout out to Dr. Noring for keeping it real and to Kara for holding it down this semester and also not letting us drop the class because I ended up with a B bc of you.

Dr. Noring is a great guy who is obviously a very experienced well known professor. I had to work for my A, I went to several study sessions and worked with his learning assistant Kara. She was wonderful at breaking down the material. She has a skill of explaining math that I have never encountered before. Actually made me enjoy math for once.
Hardest class i have taken. He doesnt really teach you anything and expects you to learn everything yourself. He told my class that he wasnt our teacher and that we were. DO NOT TAKE HIM!!!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Very passionate about math, but that doesn't make him a good teacher. His way of "teaching" is fast scrolling through the textbook, stopping only to read a couple lines verbatim, doing the example problem that has already been solved in the book, and then saying "it's that easy". Be prepared to teach yourself most concepts
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This professor is a nice guy. His lectures are pretty boring and he does get sidetracked a lot. One thing I'd take into consideration is that at the end of the semester if you have an A in the class, he will bump you down to a B if you failed just one out of the 12 tests. This is stupid to me. I should have gotten an A and instead I got a B.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I loved Dr. Noring for both my Calc 2 and Diff eq class. He going into depth about the information you will be learning, although he does go pretty fast. I recommend taking his class if you have a strong background in trigonometry. Tbh, he really does baby his students; his study guides are very similar to his tests.

I loved having Dr. Noring as my teacher, I actively wanted to go to class to learn the material despite the difficulty. He can sometimes get off topic, but overall he explains the content really well and is excited about what he is teaching. He is always ready to help students with questions during class and in office hours.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I believe this is one of the best professors you can take for math. If you go to class he will help you out with some problems you are having. There are 12 tests but they are more like quizzes and you can retake 2-3 at the end of the semester. Although all homework is due at end of semester I highly recommend you do it because it helps for tests.
Amazing professor if you are willing to listen to his lectures

His lectures are incredibly boring and not very informative. He spends the entire class on about 2 problems, and gives penalty points for each unexcused class absence. He posts study guides that are helpful, but he's not very forgiving when grading. Minor math mistakes have costed me a letter grade.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Great guy who is focused on student success, but it's hard to stay focused with him. The way he teaches is by opening the pdf of textbook, and scrolling page by page and basically ranting really fast about the material. Easy to zone out in his class. Tests are not bad though, similar to study guides. Still, hard to make an A with, but easy B.

Very passionate about math, but to the point where you lose him. Gives a LOT of homework but it is due at the end of the semester. 12 tests and you can retake three, he gives out study guide about a week prior which is basically a copy of the test. My main peeve I have is that his teaching style is just literally reading the book to teach class.

Noring isn't the most charismatic individual I've ever met, but he's certainly a great person. Calc 2 is a really hard class for a lot of people, but you will be provided with MORE than enough resources to succeed. If you fail with Noring, it's on you. Talk to him if you don't understand concepts, he will help you.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I took cal 2 and easily passed this class because he literally gives us sample exams BEFORE the tests. I could see what kind of questions will be on the tests and be able to practice it. You have alot of hw but u don't need to do all of them because you will get bonus on tests and double credit if you do chapter 8. EZ CLASS IF YOU STUDY

Dr. Noring is a great professor. He enjoys getting to know his students better. He cares for his students and wants them all to pass. He gives out a lot of homework on mymathlab and they're all due at the end of the semester, half of them are extra credit. He also gives extra credit on his tests. His tests are exactly like the study guide so do it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Dr. Noring knows math well, and he will highlight things to rememeber for future math classes. He's passionate about the subject, and he explains things well. I highly recommend taking his classes! Make sure you do your homework because it's practice, and really go over the sample tests to know what to expect from the tests.

Dr. Noring is an incredible calculus 2 professor. Calculus 2 is hard, so you have to put in the effort to actually understand whats going on. He also has an AWESOME SI. His SI is the only SI I have ever seen that actually cares about student success. She put in a ton of extra hours that i know she didnt get paid for just because she cares.

I just had Professor Noring for Trig, he's pretty great. He really cares about what he's teaching and he involves the class by asking them to help solve the problems he works out as he goes along on the board. Sometimes, when he's really passionate about a topic, he will yell at the class about it's importance. (its funny) He's super nice. WTA!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Simply put, he's a good teacher and the class isn't hard either. If you do the homework on MyMathLab ( only need 50% completion) and study the sample tests online then this class will be a breeze. You also receive bonus points for just showing up to every lecture and doing bonus homework.

uses mymathlab as all of your homework (only 50% of what he actually assigns is required; any more completed gives bonus points). if you show up to every lecture, you get bonus points too. for every test, he posts a sample test on BrightSpace which is basically the actual test with a few changes. study these and do the homework and it's an easy A/B
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He is a good professor who cares about how well students do. As long as you go to all the classes, and you practice his study guides before the test, than its an easy class. Loads of homework and he gives bonus points.
Hes kinda wild but he really knows what hes talking about. Very passionate about the subject

Noring is very passionate about the subject, even to a fault. For most students his class is agitating as he spends far too much time going on tangents rather than teaching the real skills you need for Calculus. This was the hardest class I've ever had and I ended up being self taught for the majority of the class.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: I took Dr. Noring for Calc II. I cannot recommend him enough. He knows what he is teaching and gives you what you need to succeed at his tests. He also does a great job at actually making you learn calculus. If you do good at his class, you have actually learned something. He is also very generous with extra credit and quite funny.

If you're like me and took calc AB and BC in high school (ie Calc 1 and 2), Noring is the easiest A for calculus you will ever encounter. HOWEVER, if you have never seen calc before, I do not recommend him. His practice exams are the exams with just a few numbers changed, but he's fast and the type to go on tangents. I loved him, others didn't.

He's great. I just wish he would have taught the material. There's a lot of self teaching in the hw. Can't break down hard concepts into manageable pieces. Start on the hw asap. There's a lot of it. Do the hw before class. Hw and practice test gets decent grade on test. I feel like I'm ready for calc or diff eq but not ready for his trig tests.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Honestly Dr Noring is very smart but isnt very good at breaking down the basics. I studied at least two hours everyday for this class and struggled! He is all over the place during his lectures and confused. Test questions were missed by the whole class and he got them wrong in the review. He still counted them wrong for us. Do the loads of HW.

Dr Noring was great honestly. Make sure you start the homework as soon as you get access to web assign because those extra credit points help a ton and plus theres just a lot to do. but definitely take his course. He does prepare you for your future classes.

Everything about professor noring is great. I took his calc1 summer session on TTH2-6 and he was awesome. He gives you everything you need to know for his tests and is accessible for questions etc. The only problem I had was I underestimated how much homework was required as to not have penalty points. START HW ASAP. other than that , A+ Noring!

Professor Noring is a great professor. I took him for Calc I in the summer semester and he did a good job of explaining the material. He gives practice exams a day or two before the in class exam, and they definitely helped me do well. WebAssign is required, and it is a pain, however it helps.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I earned my A by practicing the problems so much my fingers hurt. His study guides are extremely helpful though. GO TO THE SI AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE- she will walk you through the whole study guide and more. Both the SI and Noring have office hours and are easy to get a hold of outside of those hours as well. I would take again.

Calculus II is not an easy class. Review your algebra, trig and calc 1 before the semester starts. You need to be prepared to try hard, and his SI is AMAZING ( 10/10 would recommend going to her - it is very obvious she cares. She puts in 3x the amount of hours and does not get paid for them, I have never had an SI who actually cared before).
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He says figure it out at least twice a day about important sections that will be on the exam. He is teaching class from a study guide he gives you at the last minute. He is probably better at teaching Calc & Calc II but not for Trig or Pre Calc. He just assumes you know important info even though you have never taken the class before.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS, whatever you do. Professor just rushes through a couple examples and then tells you "it's not that hard" and to "figure it out". Says we learned everything in high school when we actually didn't. Tests are difficult and heavily based on logs/trig rules. Lots of useless WebAssign homework. Beware misleading positive reviews

Noring is a solid choice for a Calc II teacher if you actually care about learning the content. His class is by no means easy, but you will have left it fully understanding all of the material. Homework is completion and the majority of your grade will be from tests, so study hard. Overall, a great teacher who really cares about the subject.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I've been through Calc III and Linear algebra. ODE is very different and can easily get ahead of you. The lectures helped some, but what I can not stand is webassign, although he makes it much less brutal than any other class that I've had to use it in. He is very by the book and you will have to work for the grade you want, do all the bonuses.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Mediocre math student here; Noring will, quite exhaustively, go out of his way to help you learn/pass; you just have to show you that you are worthy of his time. Tests are hard; but, he is not that tough on grading; my tests were covered in partial credits. Key to passing Noring's class is to remember about 5 trig integrations and  1/x dx  lnx.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: The poor ratings on here, are only from people who were obviously not prepared to work hard. Calculus II is extremely challenging, you will need to study every night. SI sessions are insanely helpful, definitely attend. Dr. Noring is really here to help.

Hands down the best math professor or teacher I have ever had. He truly wants you to succeed not only in his course, but any course that would have Calc 2 in it. He is an engineer himself, so he knows what is needed for future knowledge. Incredibly passionate in his teaching. it is a tough course but Noring is the only one who can get you ready.

If you plan on continuing on to higher math classes, Dr. Noring is the professor to take. He isn't easy, but if you try in his class, you will actually learn the material and gain a good understanding of math. While his lectures are helpful, he puts a lot of emphasis on working by yourself to understand the material. Would totally recommend.

Calc 2 is one of the hardest classes you could ever take and Dr. Noring is probably one of your best bets in succeeding. I'm average in math, and I worked my butt off to get an A by religiously using Khan Academy and pouring over my lecture notes and his practice tests. Do all the extra credit, make a Khan Academy account, and get ready to cry.

Good Calc Teacher, Textbook is a Free PDF you can get from certain circles, he has homework assigned due next class which counts for 10% of the grade, about 6% of your grade is extra credit. He has small unit tests over each chapter, and has a few unit tests per actual test. He seemed to know what he was doing but I just hate calc
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Honestly, I just read the textbook while he was giving the lecture (from the textbook). He's pretty big on figuring things out on your own, so if you don't work well that way, do NOT take him. Other than that, the practice exams he posts give a good idea for the test, and he's a cool person. It's a lecture class, so no group activity things.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I really do not think you should take this class. Even if you're extremely mathematically gifted, you will struggle. He loves math and you can tell but he tests you as if you're a doctor in math as well. The tests aren't straight forward, the practice tests aren't remotely similar. I could do without the belittling comments as well. Don't take him.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: BEWARE, very very difficult exams. I am extremely good at math, made a 96% in calc one, but in this class, you are not tested on calc, you are tested on you ability to spot obscure trig ID and log rules. I would never take this man again. The words "this is easy" and "you learned this in 2nd grade" and "you learned this in HS" haunt me. Love urself
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: I worked so ridiculously hard, harder than I thought possible. I cried throughout this course on a weekly to even nightly basis. The extra credit is nice, but wouldn't be needed if the tests were not next to impossible to complete in difficulty and the amount of time we have to do them. Nice guy, yes, but very out of touch with reality.

Nice guy who loves the math he teaches but doesn't seem to care about teaching it in class. His justification for going absurdly fast through the lectures is "you should have learned this in high school". Grades at his own extremely slow pace and releases practice material when he feels like it, usually the night before a test. Frustrating but nice
rating_tags: Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Great Teacher .
So hard. His practice tests are so different from his actual tests.

The thing with Noring is that in the starting you'll feel like he doesn't give a lot of extra credit and you'll never have enough points for a decent grade, but the extra credits add up and by the end you'll get 50ish points out of 700, which is just 20 points shy of an entire grade. Tests are tougher than practice tests. Recommend him.

He is very passionate about the subject and will help anybody who wants to do good in the class. There are plenty of bonus opportunities, DO THEM ALL, It helped me pass the class. He cares about his students and is very helpful in his office hours. A real gem this professor.

If you fail one of his classes, it's your own fault. He makes everything very manageable, not to be confused with easy. Very quirky, as to be said with all super-involved math teachers. Gives perspective on how math is applied in real world scenarios.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: One of the best professors I have had in college. He is SOO passionate about math. He is open for office hours and gives lots of extra credit opportunities. He is also willing to work with you in any way. Definitely take him if you have the opportunity.

Noring was great. He would often show random music videos and funny videos before class to get us in a better mood. Be prepared to hear the words "THIS IS NOT THAT HARD" about 50,000 times. He has practice tests that are identical to the real test.

Course syllabus is weird. You get points for attendance & negative points for missing class. Once finishes the topic you have quiz & homework due; the next lecture. Partial credits in the exam. Homework is mandatory & gives credit but again gives negative points for not doing it. Don't take for calc 2 at least.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I do not recommend him at all. We had a 1 question quiz's everyday out of the 3 days I attended his class a week. So you either failed or passed those, then he makes you feel so stupid for not knowing something in class.. Basically compares our intelligence to that of a middleschooler or lower, by yelling "You learned this in 2nd grade!!".
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: One of the best professors I have ever had. There's tons of extra credit and there was an optional final for my class. He's fantastic at teaching and explaining concepts as well.
Good. Very good.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: HW is extra credit, coming to class is extra credit... EASY A if you try just a little bit.. there's test over every chapter so your not bombarded to study too much information, and quizzes are on a daily basis but they're simple. He wants you to have an A! TAKE HIM

Professor Noring is an excellent teacher that I highly recommend to anyone in need of a math course. He continuously supports his students while providing great examples of how the subject matter applies to the real world. Also, his grading system for Calc 3 is the best I've ever experienced. It both encouraged me to learn and reduced my stress.
Good professor. You'll have a quiz every class. Optional Cumulative Final Exam at the end. If you do well on quizzes and tests, you can easily get an A with all of the extra credit.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He's a solid, well meaning teacher, who I have no real complaints against. Tests are good assessments of whether or not you have studied the material, not trivial, but enough to demonstrate your knowledge. Grading system is a little complex, but makes sense once you understand it. He was willing to talk both in and outside class, and tried to help.

Noring is great. His lectures often go off on unnecessary but interesting tangents, but he covers what he needs to. There are quizzes at the beginning of class over the lesson taught the previous day, and he reviews before them. He lets you use a cheat sheet on tests, and gives plenty of chances for extra credit. The textbook was extremely helpful.

Professor Noring is a kind and intelligent professor with a strong passion for Mathematics. If you can adapt to his teaching style, you will certainly do well. I would advise those who hate class quizzes and frequent tests not to take Noring. If you have to pick between Kennesaw and Marietta, pick the Kennesaw class as he teaches at both campuses.

Seriously an awesome teacher, and person. First class I've been in at KSU that I've felt is designed for students to succeed, but he still makes you work for your grade. Attendance is "optional," but quizzes are usually at least once a week and can't be made up, plus you get bonus points for attending. If I had to take more math I'd take him.

Professor Noring is absolutely amazing! He really knows the course content and is able to teach it  well. Attendance is not mandatory but he will give you a lot more bonus points if you show up to all of the classes. Practice exams/Extra Credit for every test and for the overall course.  10/10 great professor. A must take for Calc II or Calc III!!!
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He was a phenomenal Calculus 3 professor. He made sure all students understood the material, and gives you a practice test before all exams, so students are prepared. He gives quizzes basically every class period so be prepared. But he also gives a lot of extra credit opportunities so he is setting you up for success in his class. 10/10 professor.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Noring is great! He is a kind grader and you always know what is expected of you before an exam. He really cares and wants everyone to understand the material. Be sure to go to class and have the book. A lot of his exam questions are very similar to the examples in the book. The final is also optional.

Noring is the most knowledgable calc professor I've ever had but he conveys his information in a very dry way. Grading is out of 700 points: 100 for quizzes (which are nearly daily), 400 for tests (there are 4 of them), and 200 for the final (optional). Overall an easy class as long as you do the webassign assignments. Would take noring again!

This guy is the best math teachers I have ever had in college. Wish I could have taken calc 1 and 2 w/him. Even if you don't like him personally he runs a fair class and finds a way to make calculus not as terrible as it could be. Do the homework, thoroughly review each practice exam he gives and you could easily pass w/o taking the final.

Best Clac teacher at KSU. Took him for Calc 2&3 and it was great. He really cares about you learning the material and doing well. However with that its still calc and a lot of kids in the class did struggle. So make sure you do the homework and practice test. The homework is also a great way to get bonus points.

Overall best Calc teacher there is. Relates almost everything to make things understandable to all. Offers 4-5 hours out of his own time multiple times a week to help students review, prepare, and study for his exams. Utilizes alot of trig in his problems, but its all to prepare you! Its calculus after all. Take him, take him, and take him.

Come prepared from day one! the syllabus tells you what to expect. WebAssign helped a lot but you don't want it to catch up to you. Also had SI (helped!) and exam study guides which you DEFINITELY need to look at. Overall I like how he tried to relate the class to normal life which by the end of the course you kinda come to appreciate.

STEM professors are usually tough & mean, but this guy is probably the nicest and most supportive one of them, AND is a great professor, which is an anomaly. At times tests were unnecessarily difficult, but it's calc 2, not 10th grade algebra. Tends to go on tangents, which leads to us zoning out. But overall, best STEM professor at KSU. Take him!!

I took Dr. Noring for Calc 1 and Calc 3 (would have taken for Calc 2, but it didn't fit into my schedule). He genuinely loves the subject matter, and will gladly give examples of how the stuff being taught is actually applied in the real world. He basically hands you points; you study for quizzes with extra credit, so your best bet is to do the ec.

He is a tough instructor and expects you TO KNOW the material. Not just memorizing problems, but really understanding them is a clear focus by this instructor. He does give opportunity for lots of extra credit, but you must be willing to do the work. DO THE EXTRA CREDIT! You are expected to teach yourself and STUDY! DEFINITELY take his course!

His lectures can be very confusing, so I recommend going to the SI sessions (extra credit). There is a quiz at the beginning of every class, but he takes the best two (and they help your grade). There's homework for everything learned in class, but counts as extra credit that can bump you almost two letter grades. I'm taking him again for Calc 3.

He's the type of professor who can fill up a white board in an instant. He tends to lecture very quickly and go on tangents, and typically only works out the easiest problems (hard ones are on the exams). You NEED to brush up on trig identities and functions, because they'll appear on exams. Overall the material is hard, but he's there for you.

While his engineering tangents (which are a lot) are interesting, they're not on the test. I feel like him teaching a pure math class such as calc 2 (as opposed to an engineering class) hinders him because he's SO knowledgeable. If you're an engineering major, you'll love him. If it's your last math class (i.e biology major), you'll zone out A LOT.

Definitely one of my fav math professors!! He's a nice guy and gives you a lot of opportunity to raise your grade and grades leniently!(all homework is extra credit) However I didn't learn much from the lecture that I didn't learn from the book, and the book was a lot quicker to learn from! Needless to say I spent most of the class on ESPN.

Dr. Noring was one of my favorite teachers this semester, and even though its for an extremely hard class he made it much easier to get through. Dr. Noring provides a ton of chances to raise your grade and do well. The only "downside" to his class is that there is a quiz over the last lecture almost every day, but if you go to class you'll do well.

Noring is very knowledgeable in math & gives extra credit, he tends to go on tangents A LOT, especially for engineering related things, which are not on the test. VERY easy to zone out in his class since  he just scrolls through the book and talks, & his tests are at times unnecessarily tough. Although the best calc prof at KSU, he's overrated.

Took him for calc 2 and 3. Expect to spend a lot of time in this class. Come on, it's calc 3. Exempted the final by simply working hard, not being smart. Excellent class if you aren't looking for a surprise. There are no curveballs. Gives practice exams that are identical to real test. Do those and easy homework and you'll be fine.
Dont take this class with this professor unless you have loads of time to throw at calc 2 and enjoy a challenge.  You and your gpa will regret it.  All the good reviews are misleading.

Professor Jon Noring is the only professor I have had at Kennesaw State University who has Exam Reviews before exams for about 3 hours of his own time outside of regular class periods.  He posts practice exams .  During Office Hours, he is more than patient and helpful in answering questions .  Do  Homework and Attend Class, and you will do well.

Dr. Noring made Calc 3 a very easy class. He has 4 tests & a mini quiz at the start of every class. HW is optional but if you do it quizzes & tests are easy. He also gives practice exams for every test, same format & questions just different numbers. If you have a B avg. on tests, quiz & attend most classes and do homework you can also exempt final
This class sucks.  Lectures are pointless reiterations of the hw.  Expect complex trig fcns worked into whatever concept being tested.  If you wanna exempt the final, eat/breath/sleep Calc 2.

Gives a TON of extra credit, and if you meet a list of a few requirements, you can exempt the final! Although he does give practice exams that are identical to the real test (a few numbers changed here and there), those few changes can make the test much harder since it's upper level math. Trust me, if you need to take calculus, this man is beast!!

Exams are difficult, but it's calc 2, so you can't expect it to be easy. Besides that, he is one of the best professors I've ever had. He truly cares for each student, and wants you to succeed! He is VERY knowledgeable in many fields, which at times causes him to go on a tangent during lectures, and tends to only work easy problems, but take him!!!

Nice guy but this class is not setup well for success.  Class is based on 650 point system.  4 tests  400, final  200, pop quizzes make up the last 50.  One bad test and you'll be playing catch up the rest of the year.  Bonus points are given but usually in 1/3rds.  Find hardest problems in the book because the test reflects those problems.

Concepts are not hard but the tests given varied greatly from the homework.  Usually only works out an easy version of a past test on D2L and the actual exam will test your mathematical limits.  Opt out of cumulative final only if you score above 80 on all 4 tests, 70% avg on all quizzes, attend 22/26 lectures, complete all hw before due dates.

Hands down, one of the best math teachers I ever had. Cares A LOT about his students, heck the guy stayed up one night till 4am working on a practice test! Shows how much he cares about teaching! Definitely recommend him!

Very smart man, and great professor. Those 2 are very hard to find. Highly recommend him. Gives a lot of extra credit, and is always willing to help you out. If you have to take Calc III, take it with him. Cannot recommend him enough.

Professor Noring is the best math teacher Ive had thus far.  I am a dual enrolled student who skipped many courses in math and therefore don't have a firm grasp of everything so far in math.  To make matters worse, my Calc 1 teacher was horrible and I learned almost nothing.  Noring was able able to teach at my level and I ended up with a high A.

Professor Noring is an amazing teacher. I thoroughly learned Calculus II material and found it fairly straightforward. He gives extra credit and  is always available to answer questions before and after class. It is evident that he cares for his students. Personally I thought Calculus II was easy, however a lot of students struggled.

He helped students a lot to make "A" and gave lots of extra credit opportunities.  He posted practice exam each test that was really helpful for real exam.  He is passionate and his questions and answers are always clear.  Take him! Easy A!

This is the best professor I have ever taken. He sent us an email at the end of the semester offering to us his help and advice on our future academic journies. He is such a kind man who cares for his students. I quote: "I want to have a problem at the end of the year. I want everyone to get As in this class and for KSU to be like: WHAT!?" TAKE HIM

Calc II isn't an easy class, but Dr. Noring does a great job of making it as simple as it can possibly be and his passion seriously translates. 4 exams plus a final(opt-out option)-practice exams uploaded to d2l(close to the real thing), optional homework(bonus points), quizzes(based on hw & top grades used), open to questions. great experience.

Take him for Calc 2. Really helpful and extremely kind. Wants the student to succeed so much that he gives chances to earn bonus points and gives many resources for the exams. It's Calc 2 so it is not an easy course, but he makes it as easy as it can be. One of my favorite classes I've taken at KSU. Thanks Dr. Noring!

Class is not mandatory, but you get extra credit for showing up and if you miss enough points will be deducted. If you put the time in then you will pass the class, but you have to do the homework, go to the SI sessions, and ask him for help. He is very willing to help and does everything he possibly can to help you learn the material.
Glad this year started strong, especially with a great professor! Thanks!

One of the nicest, funniest (even though I dont think he is trying to be), and enjoyable professors at KSU. He gives you a practice exam before the actual exam that is VERY similar (he just tweeks each question a tiny bit). He is very good at explaining mathematical concepts. WONDERFUL professor. No text book, just mymathlab.

Professor Noring is very passionate about the subjects he teach . He prepares his students for Calculus and is lenient with grading . He is nice and caring and has the desire to teach students. If you have a question, he will answer it . It does take a lot of studying and you have to be consistent with practicing. Bang your head against the wall

Loved this Professor! I had him for Pre-calculus and he was one of my favorite professors. He's very clear on grading and is also funny at times. I opted out of the final by passing all of my quizzes. Homework is extra credit and is meant to help you. I would recommend him to anyone, he's very helpful and he cares about his job.

I took AP Calc in high school so I just took this class for credit! Homework is optional & for bonus points which is awesome. He's always willing to answer questions and go through problems people have trouble with. He gives study guides that are exactly like the test! If you do good on tests, come to class, and do some HW you can exempt the final!

I'm not really a techy or mathy person. I am good at math, but I don't love it. Dr. Noring makes Calc 2 easy, simple, and methodical. It's hard stuff, he gives 4 tests, but he gives practice tests that are identical. Do those, you'll be completely fine. I scored no less than 99 on tests, and exempted final. Lectures are all you need, don't buy book

Best math professor I have ever had. I took him for pre-calculus and calculus. He gives you extra credit for just doing your homework. He always takes time out of class to answer any questions about the homework. There are 4 tests, and if you have good test grades and show up to class, you dont have to take the final exam.

Jon Noring is an amazing professor. I never liked math - before I took his class. He gives lots of quizzes and HW but only counts the five best quizzes and HW is all bonus points. He strives to make everyone understand and works incredibly hard to grade quickly. I'd recommend him easily, especially to those who have struggled in math in the past.

Dr. Noring really cares for his students. Calculus II is not an easy subject, but he does what he can to help you. However, he sometimes gets distracted and has to speed through the material at the end of class. He does give a lot of extra credit though. As long as you do the extra credit and go to the SI sessions, you should get an A

Great Professor. For once, someone taught me how calculus is used in real life. I learnt a lot in his class and would definitely take him again 100 times. Gives pop quizzes but reviews them before the actual quizzes. His tests are based on his practice tests. He gives tons of extra credit
He's always down to explain things, and he has an SI leader that is very helpful.
Great teacher overall.  Lots of extra credit that other teacherss do not offer.  Take him for Calc 1 and Calc 2

The class is one of the hardest classes I have ever taken. He does not help the fact that the material is not easy. He assumes that you know things that you should have learned in a previous class that no one has learned. I wouldn't take him if I were you. I got a decent grade but taught myself everything.

Dr. Noring was awesome. Gives clear lectures straight from the textbook for easy reference. He gives you extra credit for doing your homework. Class is definitely an easy A, just make sure you do My Math Lab.

His classes are easy As. He give a LOT of extra credits. He gives extra points for doing homework. Tests were so easy. He will let you skip the final If you did well on the tests. He is ready to go above and beyond to help you succeed and get a good grade. If you take this class, you should get an A

Dr. Noring loves what he teaches, and it shows.  This is a difficult class that requires many hours of work outside of class, in addition to the many SI sessions Dr. Noring arranges.  It is very important that you have a good understanding of precalculus prior to taking this course.  Do well on the practice tests to do well on the exams.

Professor Noring is easily one of the best math professors I have ever had. He is very dedicated to helping you do well. He offers to stay after class if you need help and gives excellent review sessions the day before the test. The homework is extra credit and will help you ace the tests. I highly recommend  Professor Noring.

So thankful I randomly chose him for calc 1 and i'm so glad I snagged him for calc II. Do the extra credit, go to review lessons, and do the practice exam over and over until you get it all right and you will do just fine. Super nice guy too, you can tell he cares! Just do your part and he will go above and beyond on his own behalf.

Great prof! This dude is dedicated to His students. Will stay after And do however much you need to do, just ask. He really does Provide to the tools so you can succeed but you must seek them out. DO YHE EXTA CREDIT HOMEWORK. That got me an A

Professor Noring has a great love for calculus! His lectures can be a little bit confusing bc he has a lot of knowledge and often can't explain it clearly. He is very helpful, especially if you are having a tough time. He gives you practice exams that really help clarify some of the concepts. Very nice guy.

He is a very nice guy and you can tell he has a passion for calculus. He gives practice tests which are formatted like the test. If I'm behind on the material I can usually catch up with a night or two of intense studying of the practice test. He gives extra credit through optional homework and attendance, and makes it possible to exempt the final.

The DFW (D's, F's, Withdraw)  rate for calculus is outrageous nationwide. Thats only because the teacher doesn't prepare you for the tests. Dr. Noring is one of the best at preparing his students for success. I have taken numerous of math professors and Dr. Noring is the best. Take him if you would like to succeed in any math class.
As long as you complete the optional homework and do the practice exams, you will do great in his class. He is very enthusiastic, which made the class better.

Great guy I really enjoyed this class and I hate math. He wants you to understand the stuff and really enjoys teaching it, goes out of his way to help you. You if show up you get extra credit. I loved this class, I would take him again if I have a chance to!

'My Math Lab' is bonus, but honestly, the homework didn't prepare me for his tests, and neither did his lectures.
